div.span: Please join us in participating in the BeTheLight challenge. We will be turning on the Stadium Lights in Woodhull and the School Lights in Alpha this Friday from 8:00 PM - 8:20 PM. We would like to show support for the Class of 2020 in all they are facing during this time. Please join us by turning on your front porch lights from 8:00-8:20 and post via Social Media using the hashtag "BeTheLight and lets light up the AlWood Community for the Class of 2020. Thanks.

div.div: Mrs. Winters, Mrs. Darwin and Mr. Rees have finally heard back from Lavender Crest, the DJ that was hired for the Prom and from the company that is providing the Prom Photo Booth and everything has been arranged. The AlWood Prom is now scheduled to take place on Saturday May 23 at Lavender Crest.

If in the event that the Governor orders that school remain closed past the current April 30 date, then Mrs. Winters, Mrs. Darwin and Mr. Rees will meet and work to come up with a new plan. As stated before, we will do everything we can to make sure that AlWood has a 2020 Prom.

font.span: Dear AlWood High School Students, Staff, and Families

p.span: The AlWood Prom scheduled for April 18, 2020, has been postponed. Mrs. Winters, Mrs. Darwin (the Junior Class Sponsors) and Mr. Rees are currently exploring options for rescheduling Prom at a later date. We will contact you when we know more. Thank you.

span.font: Dear AlWood School District Students, Staff, and Families,

On Friday, March 27th, the Illinois State Board of Education directed districts to transition to Remote Learning Days beginning March 31st in anticipation of an extended school closure beyond the current April 7th executive order. We recognize that this development may raise questions about the impact on students, staff, and families as well as the school’s vital role of providing meals to students and families while schools are closed.

AlWood Schools will be utilizing Tuesday, March 31st as a Remote Learning Planning Day in order to help staff prepare continuing content for students. We anticipate delivering new content either electronically or in print beginning Monday, April 6th. Meal service will continue as planned during this time.

Please use this opportunity to focus on staying safe and helping to slow the spread of the virus. As always, thank you for your patience and support as we all work through the COVID-19 Pandemic. As you have seen, this situation is evolving rapidly. As events unfold, we will continue to communicate in a timely and transparent manner.

On Friday, March 20th, Governor Pritzker issued an executive order requiring residents to “stay at home” effective Saturday, March 21 at 5:00 pm, through the end of April 7. As part of the Governor’s order, he announced that school will remain closed, with a new tentative reopening date of April 8. We recognize that this development may raise questions about the impact on students, staff, and families as well as the school’s vital role of providing meals to students and families while schools are closed. We anticipate further guidance and details from the Illinois State Board of Education next week.

font.span: uring this stay at home order, essential school personnel may still report to work as long as they are practicing social distancing. W

e want you to know the governor’s office has assured school districts that school personnel involved in providing meals will not be in violation of the governor’s executive order and that we can, and should, continue with our program, which will have a tremendous impact in making sure our students are not going hungry while school is closed.
In addition, the governor has made it clear that, while he’s serious about using social distancing to slow the spread of COVID-19, he wants residents to still be able

to work, shop at grocery stores, put gas in their cars, take walks outside and get medication from the pharmacy. Rest assured, we are committed to doing our best to provide meals and deliver continuity of education.

span.font: Please use this opportunity to focus on staying safe and helping to slow the spread of the virus. As always, thank you for your patience and support as we all work through the COVID-19 Pandemic. As you have seen, this situation is evolving rapidly. As events unfold, we will continue to communicate in a timely and transparent manner.

This past week, there has been a great deal of news published about the Coronavirus/COVID-19. As you know, our schools and activities will be closed through Monday, March 30th. Our district has been proactive in considering the health and safety of our students.
Moving forward, we would like to offer guidance on how things will be handled during the mandatory shut down times:
Breakfast and lunch meals will be free for students
Available for pickup in the lobby of the elementary school and the high school
Pickup times will be: Monday, Wednesday, Friday from 8:00 a.m. to 10:00 a.m.

For the duration of the closure, we encourage you to keep your child’s mind occupied with learning opportunities. Consider developing a daily schedule for your child that incorporates time for academics, quiet reading, and physical activity.
Enrichment work and activities will be made available for students in all grade levels. Links will be shared by teachers via Class Dojo (elementary) and Google Classroom (JH/HS).
Enrichment work and activities won’t be mandatory, nor will they be graded or turned in.
Student grades will be frozen, and will remain the same until school classes resume. Any work completed during the closure will not be counted towards grades.
Grades K-3 will have packets of materials available for pick up during the meal pick up times on Monday, Wednesday, and Friday.

If your child does not have his/her chromebook those may be picked up during the meal pick up times Monday, Wednesday, and Friday. This includes students in grades 5th-8th. If a student needs something from their locker, arrangements can be made during the meal pick up times.

font.span: If parents need to access critical student medications and medical supplies that are housed at the school, those items may also be picked up starting March 23
during the meal pick up times.
Otherwise, special arrangements can be made by contacting the building principals.

p.span: Dear AlWood School District Students, Staff, and Families,

The health and safety of our students and staff is our top priority, so we want to share information that the Illinois State Board of Education (ISBE) and the Illinois Department of Public Health (IDPH) have published for schools throughout the state.

The good news at this time is that the health risk to the general public from coronavirus remains low. Currently, the IDPH recommends schools hold classes and events as usual and follow routine cleaning and disinfecting procedures; no special measures are necessary.
The IDPH also recommends the best way to protect against coronavirus is by taking the same everyday precautions against getting sick in general. These include:
● Washing your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds.
● Avoiding touching your eyes, nose, and mouth with unwashed hands.
● Avoiding close contact with people who are sick.
● Staying home when you are sick.
● Covering your cough or sneeze with a tissue, then throw the tissue in the trash.
● Cleaning and disinfecting frequently touched objects and surfaces.

To see the complete recommendations to schools from ISBE and IDPH, please click here. We will continue to closely monitor recommendations regarding coronavirus and will update you as soon as there are any significant changes in recommendations for schools. Thank you for your support in helping to keep our school community healthy.
